ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: about 2 per week plus 10-15 during the midterm and final.
About 2/week. Mideterm week= ~25 total
5 hours
5 hours
2-3 hours
5 (varies, spent at least 20 hours on the midterm)
2 hours
Usually 1 to 2 for homework, but given the time commitment for the midterm and final I would say it averages out to about 4.
I spent about 2-3 hours per week.
6 hours per week
2 hours for a normal week, I spent about 8-14 on each exam.

For the weekly homework assignments, I would spend 3-5 hours on them. For the midterm, I spent 7-10 hours throughout the entire week we had to work on the midterm assignment. I spent a majority of the 48 hours available to complete the final take-home assignment.
5 hours
Depended on the week, but between readings and assignments 5-7. More on weeks during midterm and final.
3 hours per week, excluding time for take home exams.
3-4 hours
I usually spend between 2 and 3 hours on cases each week. I spent around 12 hours on the midterm and about the same amount of time on the final.
2-3 hours for weekly assignments. About 10 hours for the midterm and final.
approx 3 hours
6 hours

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: Could be faster paced and more in-depth. A more "real world" analysis would have been interesting i.e. write a paper that does a complete cost effectiveness analysis.
This course is excellent.

The course is well organized and very relevant. I found it difficult to coordinate getting outside help on the course until it was more of a crisis situation. I understand the need for time management for both TAs but they should at least be willing to meet with people who ask for help in order to assess whether the student is indeed not "getting it" or is just wanting someone to hold their hand!

Fantastic! This course was the best course, not only this semester, but also in my five years at Yale. The material was interesting, the professor engaging, funny, and smart, and the all the different factors combined to result in a highly enjoyable class. Wildly practical for almost everyone, no matter what field you end up going into, this course is about a way of thinking. The professor was incredibly engaging and funny, making each class a joy. I could not wait to attend lecture each week. The problem sets are truly there to help one learn, not to punish or torture. The class is flexible enough to accommodate anyone's schedule. I could not write a more favorable review than this. I have never written such glowing terms for a class, so I apologize that I don't have practice in effectively communicating my thoughts.

Need to spend more time actually learning the material rather than going through studies/research. I can't understand the studies/research if I don't understand the concepts. Not enough time spent actually teaching/reviewing the material. Also, the midterm was very hard.

I enjoyed the material, the instructor, his engagement with the class, and his willingness to meet the needs of his students. I think it would be helpful to get more examples and practice with skills he wanted us to learn well. He videotaped the classes, which were awesome to go back and reference the lecture.

Strengths - learned hard skills that will transfer to work environment Weaknesses - felt as though I didn't learn the material well enough to complete the test questions. Disconnect between the cases and the evaluations. I liked how you made the excel templates and slides available before class. It made taking notes a lot easier and it also helped me follow along during the excel examples. Thank you!
This class is perfect in every aspect.
Professor makes the course more interesting/enjoyable.
Its awesome. I loved everything about it. Definitely keep the Homework as mandatory. The forcing function certainly helped with success.

I don't think this was a great introduction class for someone who has little experience in cost effectiveness and analysis. I felt like I needed an economics class or another business class to have understood more of the material. The midterm was ridiculous. I hate exams that have questions that need knowledge far beyond the scope of what has been taught in class, and in the reading. I know grading was very generous with these questions, but I just got more confused instead of having the topics reinforced.
This class was great for learning how to make a decision tree and conduct cost-effectiveness. Video podcasts were extremely helpful for reviewing concepts again.
A very fun and useful course. No weaknesses
very useful, strongly recommended

First of all, this is my favorite class this semester! I love the instructor's lecturing style because I find it very thought-provoking... The way how he encourages students' participation is very inviting. The course materials are interesting and learning objectives are well communicated - very well plugged in with what's going on in current public health topics.

The course set up is slightly different than what I'm used to. There's a heavy emphasis on self-directed learning. You can't discuss the homework with the TAs until after the submission which I say is detrimental to the learning process, however, I did just fine.
i really enjoyed the class and the course materials
Thought it was a good course. Not sure if I learned much about cost effectiveness analysis, per se, but learned a lot of excel and probabilities.
An awesome class! Provided insight into an area I was seriously lacking in before.

Strengths- Paltiel is very enthusiastic and fun to have as a lecturer. I feel like in the end I did learn some interesting aspects of CE Weaknesses- Since the class is quite dense and quite self-taught, the topics sometimes take awhile to wrap your head around (or my head). I attended lecture but a lot of the concepts went so over my head I ended up having to carefully re-watch everything during the midterm and final. I am wondering if brining a laptop to class and following along on excel and then submitting the document at the end of class for a participation grade would be useful.
I really enjoyed the course and feel like I learned a lot.
A great course. Could use more fireworks, but Winslow has a low ceiling.
Strengths - great lectures Weaknesses - none.

I thought this class was one of my best for the semester. It was not a giant time commitment but still provided plenty of work that is practical and useful for the future. The homework is helpful in learning the material and challenging in a good way. It would be a little better if the lectures preceded the homework, but I am not sure which way is better. Struggling through the cases and then reviewing in class is helpful, so long as they are reviewed in class. Grading the homework would not be recommended since everyone is mostly learning it for the first time.
Course was self-taught and lectures weren't really necessary. Wish we got more practice problems.

This was a self taught course. Strengths: It is a practical course, in which you can apply what you learn in different aspects of your professional practice Weaknesses: It was a self taught course, with no feedback on your work. Before every class we had to submit a homework, and during the class the teacher would go over the homework.
This was by far my favorite class this semester. I've always been intimidated by probability, but David really breaks it down so that you understand. The exams are challenging but very doable.
I would suggest more homework problems that are similar to the ones on the exams. Also, it would be great to dedicate the lecture before the exam to going over the practice exam that was given to us.
Very good introduction to economic/analytic methods in evaluating public health interventions.

The homework is a useful tool, and when we go over it in class as a group, it is particularly helpful. However, we did not always get to all of the homework during the class period, which made some of the homework assignments feel like an unnecessary exercise. If more attention could be paid to going over all of the homework assignments for each relevant class period, this would greatly improve the course.
Really interesting and easy to digest even for a non-econ person. Really interesting supplemental perspective I gained as a CDE candidates.

Useful to get an introduction to this kind of analytical thinking, and the professor was friendly and approachable. Lectures were too long, however, and the time was not always well used. Individuals with stupid questions often diverted the course of instruction, with the effect of interrupting our trains of thought and interfering with the absorption of new material. Classes also danced around providing a straightforward explanation of how to conduct the various analyses, and going back through lecture videos for an explanation was often a frustrating scavenger hunt with lots of repetition and only glancing mention of the information we needed. More formal/formulaic explanations and study tools would be extremely helpful.

I took this course because a few students in the class above me highly recommended this course. I am greatly disappointed with the course and wish that I had taken the similar course offered at SOM instead. First of all, the course material is something that needs to be taught by the professor, not self taught. The weekly assignments are like games to see how well you can teach the course material to yourself. This kind of course needs to be smaller, more hands on, and have discussion sections. The large lecture room does not work well for this course. Also, Professor Paltiel is not an effective teacher. After receiving some bad feedback on the comment cards he passed out, he asked us to give more feedback because he thought it was other circumstances that led to the bad feedback. His teaching was the cause of the bad feedback.

Strengths- Great practical skills to learn (Cost effectiveness). Professor is amazing. Weaknesses- It can be difficult to master these skills if you are not quantitative or mathematical in nature. The posted readings to teach us the concepts are not the best so self learning is definitely involved. Also the midterm and final took me soooo many hours; just something to be aware of. Improvements- Give us feedback on our hw. Keep posting slides before lecture.

The materials are very interesting. Recordings of the course are extremely helpful. It would have been more helpful to have handouts of the excel sheets used in class so it would be easier to follow in the lecture, instead of looking at different screens.
There is a tremendous amount of self-teaching in this course. Had I not been taking a similar course concurrently, I think I really would have struggled. That said I really like Professor Paltiel.
Great course. Interesting material and taught in a very thought provoking way. Enjoyed pedagogical style.
I liked that we walked through the homework/examples of how to do problems from start to finish in-class.
Good course! Very well structured, builds a good skill set.

Strengths: such an important skill and potentially tedious to learn, but Dr. Paitel was an amazing professor and made it fun! Weaknesses: sometimes the homeworks were difficult to do on one's own without prior knowledge--good thing is was pass/fail.

Strengths of this course -- material was useful, certainly not something that I would have learned myself otherwise. However, the first part of the course involving probability trees seemed at times redundant because I could not see myself drawing trees in the working world (outside of academia). I did find the CEA part very useful though. I would like an updated and clearer set of slides, though. The cobalt blue background was quite hard to read on sometimes, even up close!!
I feel like the assignments would have been more meaningful if distributed AFTER the course material was taught, as the 'learn by doing' method made coming to class seem less effective.

I thought that the course was very interesting. I had never had any introduction to the principles covered, so it was fun to realize that I really like decision analysis and cost-effectiveness analysis. That being said, I usually felt like the classes could be half as long and the course could have been half as long. We would spend time going over material that wasn't exactly relevant, and we also had a few classes where we didn't learn any new material. I also want to take a second here to talk about the requirement for health policy students. I think this course should DEFINITELY continue to be a requirement because I am someone who, just looking at the course description, would have said "no way." Yet, I loved the material covered in this course. One thing, though, is I wish that we were instructed to take this course in the FIRST YEAR. I would have loved to continue on with this material by taking Ed Kaplan's policy modeling class, but that is no longer an option for me. (It would also be nice to have something geared more toward policy students who may have less of a background with the math considering it is a requirement for the policy program).
Very difficult course
very nice instructor, informative content, it's also helpful and do not have much workload
The way the knowledge is delivered should be re-examined. There is a lot of room for improvement here.
This class provided me with tangible skills. Lectures were interesting.

This course really opens your mind to a different way of thinking, and teaches very useful skills. The homework can be long and tedious, but I was happy to do every problem, since many of the concepts can be difficult to understand without going through the process yourself. I felt there was a good mix of theory, example problems, and real world application over the course of the semester.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: A David Paltiel  Lectures are good to very good with the above caveat.
Instructor: A David Paltiel  Absolutely excellent. Clear, engaging lectures. Always went over the homeworks in class.

Instructor: A David Paltiel  Dr. Paltiel is an engaging instructor that presents information that is very relevant to the real-world and to studen'ts learning needs. Sometimes I found the slides presented to not be as explicit as I needed in order to get the right answers. This was more of an issue in the pre-midterm material than in the last section of the class which was more Excel based and therefore more explicit.

Instructor: A David Paltiel  Professor Paltiel is a gem. I shudder to think what would have happened to this material if attempted by another professor. Professor Paltiel brought his incredible experience and humor to make this class incredible. The class is so successfully only because of Paltiel.
Instructor: A David Paltiel  excellent instructor, kept the atmosphere fun

Instructor: A David Paltiel  I really enjoyed having class with Dr. Paltiel! He is funny, engaging and incredibly smart. Sometimes, though, I think he loses sight of HOW advanced he is and can make problems more complicated than the skill level he teaches.
Instructor: A David Paltiel  Great!
Instructor: A David Paltiel  He is well prepared for class materials as well as his jokes haha. His class was very engaging. Like him a lot!
Instructor: A David Paltiel  Very funny. Thanks!
Instructor: A David Paltiel  Very engaging professor, covered a good range of topics mixed with applications.
Instructor: A David Paltiel  Accessible, entertaining, great lecturer. Wants students to succeed.
Instructor: A David Paltiel  Very funny guy. He was considerate of students, and approachable.

Instructor: A David Paltiel  Lectures after the midterm started to coordinate better with the cases. Before, the lectures were sometimes too slow, and could have covered more than one homework question. More exposure to questions prior to the midterm would be helpful so we could be better prepared for the midterm.
Instructor: A David Paltiel  Yale would not be the same without this amazing professor. I am glad I had the chance to be in his class.
Instructor: A David Paltiel  very excellent

Instructor: A David Paltiel  Love him! He offers a spectrum of level of commitment to the material we are learning for each session, which is what I think a graduate school level course should be like. The class meeting time is a little awkward, wish it met twice a week with shorter session time instead.
Instructor: A David Paltiel  He is very energetic and passionate about his work. He's willing to collect feedback but slightly difficult to change based on the feedback.
Instructor: A David Paltiel  I though the instructor was great, really good at explaining the material and keeping everyone interested and involved
Instructor: A David Paltiel  Very engaging with the students. Responsive, attentive.
Instructor: A David Paltiel  A lot of fun. Knowledgeable, but also not afraid to admit he didn't know something and willing to entertain new ideas.
Instructor: A David Paltiel  Humorous and engaging lectures
Instructor: A David Paltiel  Very enthusiastic and fun. Sometimes repetitive, but this is a class that needs it, and amazing at making up test questions
Instructor: A David Paltiel  Dr. Paltiel was great at explaining the concepts and keeping the class engaged.
Instructor: A David Paltiel  A charming rake.

Instructor: A David Paltiel  Dr. Paltiel is amazing. He's a great lecturer. He's very attentive to students' suggestions and gives a logical explanation behind his decisions (i.e., require textbooks vs. not require textbooks, format of exams). He also provides examples from his own work, which reinforce the lecture materials and give conviction to the relevance of the course.

Instructor: A David Paltiel  Dr. Paltiel is an enthusiastic and brilliant professor.This class could have easily been a difficult 2 hour lecture to get through each week but his teaching style is both effective and engaging. I would keep that all up and continue to use feedback from students to adapt the course as needed each year. The biggest thing I would call out is some of the material on the midterm and final. While I thought both exams were fair, testing on things that were clearly stated in class as never being expected to answer on a test is frustrating. If we did not have the video recordings of the lectures things may have been pretty bad. Not being able to review these things or have questions answered about them, because it is an exam, is especially challenging. In particular, I think we should have had a homework about the ROC curve because it was still such new material that wasn't fully reviewed in class, and worth such a larger portion of the test grade. Same for the two questions on the final that were "tricky" but 15 points each. Overall, I would happily take another course with Dr. Paltiel and really enjoyed this one.
Instructor: A David Paltiel  Teacher taught material pretty well, but half of lecture was spent on non-course related material and couldve been dedicated to more practice problems.
Instructor: A David Paltiel  Great sense of humor, and you can tell he really cares about student feedback.
Instructor: A David Paltiel  Fun, dynamic professor, and responsive to our the class' concerns. I enjoyed the occasional lecture on his current research work.
Instructor: A David Paltiel  Very enthusiastic, clear, and knowledgeable. Some times the course felt it was going a little slow.

Instructor: A David Paltiel  I greatly appreciate Professor Paltiel's dynamic and engaging teaching style. I find him to be strong at explaining the material, and always willing to go over and re-exlplain everything. On the whole, I found his class to be highly entertaining and enjoyable.
Instructor: A David Paltiel  Amazing lecturer. Really engaging guy and he can very effectively balance his professionalism and friendliness with the students.

Instructor: A David Paltiel  Energetic, friendly, good sense of humor, firm grasp on material. Slides were a mix, however, and often contained unnecessary or irrelevant information that made review more difficult. Lectures were scheduled too long, though it was good of Professor to release us early when we made it through the day's slides. A TA section would have been helpful for making sure our understanding of the methods was sound.

Instructor: A David Paltiel  Professor Paltiel is very responsive to student needs and concerns. He actively seeks feedback again and again until he is satisfied with the kind of feedback he receives. As mentioned in the last response, he passed out comment cards twice because he was unhappy with some of the bad feedback he received the first time he passed out the comment cards. His teaching is lacking. He warned us that the first half of the course is more "self-taught". Why should I have taken this course at all is he won't teach us? Even when we entered the second half of the course, I still had to "self-teach" myself.

Instructor: A David Paltiel  Strengths-Amazing, engaging, passionate about the topic..he is the only one that can make a topic like cost effectiveness interesting. Best professor at YSPH Weaknesses- none I can think off.
Instructor: A David Paltiel  I think Dr. Paltiel really took comments from the midterm into consideration for the final.
Instructor: A David Paltiel  Entertaining professor and interesting topic.
Instructor: A David Paltiel  Very enthusiastic and extremely knowledgeable - almost to a fault. Sometimes moves a little quickly for those with no experience in the subject matter.
Instructor: A David Paltiel  Good at explaining different ways of thinking through a problem, good pacing, and funny.
Instructor: A David Paltiel  David is awesome!!
Instructor: A David Paltiel  No weaknesses--perfect! He was fun and helpful and taught the course so well!!! I miss him already!
Instructor: A David Paltiel  Bubbly guy who really enjoys CEA. He is very sensitive to feedback, which is nice.
Instructor: A David Paltiel  Great knowledge of subject, and able to explain concepts well. Though the first half of the course should have been more instructive.

Instructor: A David Paltiel  Dr. Paltiel is super engaging and entertaining (yes, I think your jokes are funny). That being said, he sometimes goes quickly through things where he could spend more time and slowly through things that we have been over several times. In all, I enjoyed coming to class, so that should say something.
Instructor: A David Paltiel  good lectures, but it was still hard to complete assignments. needed more instruction/help with assignments.
Instructor: A David Paltiel  very nice instructor. I like him.
Instructor: A David Paltiel  Excellent teacher with a highly engaging teaching methodology

Instructor: A David Paltiel  Very energetic, engaging and interested in his students. Great lecturer. I liked when he presented his own work to show practical applications of the subject matter. He also clearly invested a lot of time making exams and homework assignments more enjoyable through his creativity and humor.

Instructor: A David Paltiel  Always an entertaining lecturer, you never get bored. He did a good job explaining the homework problems, answering questions, and going through examples in class. I liked the overall set up of the class and the classwork.

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: No contact
Interesting and useful.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student if they have any interest in healthcare and understanding the decisions that may be needed to be made in the field based on costs. Although one may not use the specific decision tree or modeling analyses ever depending on the line of work, the understanding you gain is essential.
Not at all what I expected or hoped this class would be. Paltiel is very nice and a good professor, just did not enjoy the course. Too much weight on midterm and final exams.
I would recommend this class to another student and tell them that it tackles difficult material.

TAKE TAKE TAKE! This course was the best of my five years at Yale. The material is fascinating and practical across all fields, and the professor is a true gem. The course is flexible enough to fit into anyone's schedule. You would be remiss to graduate without taking this course.
I would recommend this course to another student because of the skills I learned.
Great class to learn more about cost effectiveness analysis; however, your often left to figure it out on your own.
Yes it is a fantastic class!!!
Yes, Awesome course!
If you have some background in this area this would be a useful class.
Great course, lots of work, expect to attend office hours.
Definitely recommend to students. A wonderful course
strongly recommend
I was recommended by fellow students to take this class and I'm so glad that I did! You should too.
This course presents a lot of new concepts that can be used in many different settings. I fully enjoyed the material although the course's framework can be improved.
Would recommend to others
Highly recommended. Public health is all about allocation of limited resources, and even if your work doesn't directly involve cost it is important to keep in mind.

I would recommend this if you are quantitatively strong, but I know I had a hard time with the tests so I would not recommend it to others if they do not want to make a decent (and sometimes frustrating) time commitment
I would highly recommend this course.
An interesting course on cost effectiveness and analysis as applied to decision-making and healthcare. The professor is an accomplished and engaging instructor of Falstaffian character.

Summary: this course introduces concepts about decision-making and teaches approaches to making cost-effectiveness analysis. I would definitely recommend this course because it is an excellent way to understand how people could make decisions from an economic perspective. And, it's fun!

This course will probably be one of the most useful classes in my time at Yale. The skills are practical to many paths after graduation and even if they do not get applied, they are important to understand. Not everything will make sense at first but it all comes together at the end if you put in the work. Plus, Dr. Paltiel is a great lecturer and is a brilliant professor.
You get to learn about a new area, but it would be great to learn more excel in the process. Expect to teach yourself how to do problems and go to TAs for help.
Everyone should take it!
This was a difficult class for me, but I found it rewarding in the end. I think it's a practical skill to have.
I would recommend it to all M.P.H. students.
Really interesting and valuable even as a background course.

Worth taking, if only for developing a familiarity with this way of thinking. Not the most efficient use of class time but about par for YSPH. Bring your computer and follow along in Excel (we should have been told this on day one).
If this is not a required course for you, do not take it. You are likely better off taking the similar course offered at SOM.

Great skill to learn if you are able to put in the time and energy. I would only take this class if you are actually interested in the topic. Don't take if you are not a big fan of probability or quantitative work
Helpful material but I wish it was taught differently.
This course is very interesting, but a lot of work to understand the material.
A very interesting course regarding decisions made in healthcare with costs as a consideration. Teaches great analytical skills and analysis that will be very helpful in the future.
This course teaches useful skills and ways of thinking about problems; the homework and exams are also the most fun out of all the ones I've taken at YSPH.
Highly recommend!
Take it!! It's an amazing course and you learn a lot!
Recommend for the usefulness of the material.

I would say that this class is a great introduction to decision analysis and cost-effectiveness analysis. The cases are fun and interesting (not graded- which I think is a great policy from someone who actually did quite well on them). The midterm and final are very time consuming, but can be done in one day. I would probably recommend this class, but I think there is definitely a certain type of student who should take it, so I would be careful who I recommended to. Since I don't know where else to put this I also want to take a second to complain about the use of questions on the final exam for which we did not have appropriate instruction. While this is nice for people who are good at extrapolating/have experience in these concepts through other courses etc./ it is not helpful/should not be indicative of those students who consistently preformed well in this course and were engaged with the material.
very difficult class
a very good course. not much workload. nice instructor and it's very helpful.

Summary: This course teaches students the balance between costs and benefits and how to navigate the terrain. Very applicable to many fields including, clinical practice, strategy consulting, public sector etc.
I would recommend this class, especially for non-HPM students who may otherwise have no exposure to the subject.
A very useful and practical course, I am very happy to have taken it. Recommend.
